result.markdown:
## Exercise 1
1. Download the data set [`characters`](https://github.com/nickhaf/r_tutorial/tree/main/raw_data). 
1. Load it into R, and assign the name `characters`. 

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## Hint

It is a `.rds` file.
:::

::: {.callout-caution collapse="true"}
## Solution

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
characters <- readRDS(file = here::here("raw_data", "characters.rds"))
```
:::

:::


## Exercies 2
:::: {.callout-note collapse="true" icon=false}

## Advanced exercise

1. Download the [`psych_stats`](https://github.com/nickhaf/r_tutorial/tree/main/raw_data) data set.
1. Load it into R and assign the name `psych_stats`. Did that work as expected? If not, why not?

::: {.callout-tip collapse="true"}
## Hint
Take a look at the `.csv` file by opening it in a text editor. Look at the documentation of `read.csv()` and take a look at the `sep` argument. Can you define another separator, so R can deduce, which elements need to be separated into different cells?
:::

::: {.callout-caution collapse="true"}
## Solution
Let's try the `read.csv()` function:

::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
psych_stats <- read.csv(file = here::here("raw_data", "psych_stats.csv"))

head(psych_stats)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  char_id.char_name.uni_id.uni_name.question.personality.avg_rating.rank.rating_sd.number_ratings
1                                   1;F2;Monica Geller;F;Friends;messy/neat;neat;95.7;9;11.7;1079
2   2;F2;Monica Geller;F;Friends;disorganized/self-disciplined;self-disciplined;95.2;27;11.2;1185
3                           3;F2;Monica Geller;F;Friends;diligent/lazy;diligent;93.9;87;10.4;1166
4                             4;F2;Monica Geller;F;Friends;on-time/tardy;on-time;93.8;34;14.3;236
5              5;F2;Monica Geller;F;Friends;competitive/cooperative;competitive;93.6;56;13.4;1168
6                  6;F2;Monica Geller;F;Friends;scheduled/spontaneous;scheduled;93.4;23;14.5;1173
```
:::
:::

Huh, that looks weird. If we take a look at the file by opening it in a text editor, we can see that the values are seperated by `;`. 
So let's call the help for `read.csv()`:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
?read.csv
```
:::


The `sep` argument specifies that the seperator needs to be a white space (meaning tabs, spaces ... - look at the details in the documentation).  
So, we can do the following:


::: {.cell}

```{.r .cell-code}
psych_stats <- read.csv(
  file = here::here("raw_data", "psych_stats.csv"),
  sep = ";"
)

head(psych_stats)
```

::: {.cell-output .cell-output-stdout}
```
  char_id     char_name uni_id uni_name                      question
1      F2 Monica Geller      F  Friends                    messy/neat
2      F2 Monica Geller      F  Friends disorganized/self-disciplined
3      F2 Monica Geller      F  Friends                 diligent/lazy
4      F2 Monica Geller      F  Friends                 on-time/tardy
5      F2 Monica Geller      F  Friends       competitive/cooperative
6      F2 Monica Geller      F  Friends         scheduled/spontaneous
       personality avg_rating rank rating_sd number_ratings
1             neat       95.7    9      11.7           1079
2 self-disciplined       95.2   27      11.2           1185
3         diligent       93.9   87      10.4           1166
4          on-time       93.8   34      14.3            236
5      competitive       93.6   56      13.4           1168
6        scheduled       93.4   23      14.5           1173
```
:::
:::

This looks better!

:::
